7 Farm Adventures in Chattanooga

    #outdoors
Original Author: Jack Burnham - Local Guide
Last Updated: 08/08/2024
A classic barn with simple tools showcasing rural charm
Chattanooga isn't just situated among mountains outside of scenic city; it's also home to many agricultural attractions that help form a strong bond with the Earth. The farms in this region offer something for everyone, whether you are passionate about sustainable farming practices or simply seeking a tactile experience of rural life. A couple of particularly impressive areas to learn about the local agricultural scene include Crabtree Farms and Hidden Hills Farm & Saddle Club. Crabtree Farms offers a different type of urban farming experience, rooted in sustainability and community involvement — it's a comprehensive counterpoint to much smaller Ivory Red programs as well as the largest producers that are thriving throughout Chattanooga. Meanwhile, Hidden Hills Farm &Saddle Club provides an authentic taste of rural living with equestrian offerings and family-friendly events that draw people who crave time in the great outdoors. Being places full of life and a land abundant with produce, both farms celebrate the farming culture that has sustained their region; offering interactive ways to experience what this place offers!

1.  Crabtree Farms

Location: 1000 E 30th St, Chattanooga, TN 37407

Crabtree Farm is a great example of why urban agriculture should be integrated into city planning – not only does it make use of prime real estate, but can serve as an incredible space for growing food and bringing the community together. This farm was founded in 1998 and now its a bastion of the Chattanooga community.

Highlights include a 5-acre demonstration farm with unique and heirloom crops. On one side of the dog park is an acre a community garden boasting 41 organic plots for lease by area residents from March through November. There is also a seasonal farm stand that runs from April to November, which opens on Fridays and Saturdays at 10am-3pm providing fresh produce, herbs, flowers as well co-op items.

Most of you are familiar with the big events at Crabtree Farms, like our Spring and Fall Plant Sales. These sales allow a comprehensive choice of plants and vegetable begins that do well in the Chattanooga Valley at large. Food talks will also be complemented by educational workshops offering experience in sustainable gardening, canning and more.

Crabtree Farms plant sales occur annually in April and September, although you can visit when the farm stand is open May through July. Families flock to the farm in May, June and July for berry-picking; hence their pick-your-own comparisons.

2.  Hidden Hills Farm & Saddle Club

Location: 1106 Pine Hill Road, McDonald, TN 37353

Owners Lindsey and Drew Hawley have made sure to offer a family-friendly stop: Hidden Hills Farm & Saddle Club in Ooltewah, TN. Drive just outside of Chattanooga and find yourself on this 200-acre farm that gives guests an authentic piece of "country living" with access to the outdoors, along with interaction time with animals.

Some of the earliest ordinances established in Hidden Hills were for its extensive equestrian program. The farm provides services from horse boarding, riding lessons and guided trail rides. The trail rides are very popular, taking you on a one-hour journey through the farm's scenic bridle paths. Rides are available Sunday to Friday by reservation and cater to all levels of riders, though the pace is walk-only. As the rides are run for small groups, visitors should book in advance, especially during peak seasons.

Hidden Hills Farm is a great place for families with younger kids. One of the best weekend events they hold are their Farm Play Days, which are scattered throughout the year. They are designed to be places where kids can take place in free play — everything from chicken wrangling, a pony ride and hayrides. These play days for kids 6 and younger -- but all ages can join in the fun, ya'll!

For older kids, the farm hosts summer horsemanship camps that are more structured but no less fun. There is an option for beginners through to experienced riders, so everyone can be involved in a camp that best matches their skill sets. Beyond riding and horse care, the camps involve crafts as well as other outdoor pursuits that together offer a rounded introduction to farm life.

Hidden Hills Farm 1106 Pine Hill Road, McDonald TN Hidden Hills is just a short drive from Chattanooga. The farm has a very family friendly ambiance and is all-in-all fantastic for nature vibes one-day outing. A common statement from visitors is about how peaceful life on the farm seems to be and other surrounding things that remind them of their friendly, informed staff eager to show you what heaven looks like.

Be sure to check out the Farm Play Days or schedule a trail ride in the spring, summer and fall! As the activities are set outdoors, it might be a good idea to come dressed for the weather and with some spare clothes for kids (particularly if there has been recent rain!). Events and scheduling are posted on the farm's Facebook page
Crops growing in a farm field

3.  Mayfield Dairy Farms

Location: 806 E. Madison Ave., Athens, TN

Outside of Philadelphia, visitors will also have a chance to explore the farm where Borden's iconic Elsie lived as well as see how cheese is made (Bowie Cheese Farm) and try some curds fresh off the line at Whey Creamery in Lancaster County Mayfield Dairy Farms – Athens, TN This location offers guests a closer look behind one Southeast most favorite dairy brands rooted on land nestled between Chattanooga Knoxville

The heart of Mayfield Dairy Farms is the Visitor Center, which gives guests a tour of its production facility. This isn't just a tour behind the doors of the factory, it's more like an awesome and in-depth experience on how Mayfield milk & ice cream are made. Visitors can see what makes a difference in the Mayfield products during their bottling line to video presentation on ice cream production. At the end of our tour is a big favorite with everyone — A FREE scoop of Mayfield's world famous ice cream in their old-timey parlor that smacks you back into memory lane.

Families enjoy Mayfield Dairy Farms Worthy of educational tours and a grand experience for the children, so that they can realise their favorite dairy treats are not all plastic cheese slices from King Gimmenme. They also get to meet Maggie the Cow (farm mascot). The relaxed and casual atmosphere makes it great for families too. Children Should love the (interactive) experience of seeing how chocolate is made, along with ice cream.

The Visitor Center serves more than just a tour stop. A fully stocked gift shop, selling a variety of Mayfield branded products are also available- when you drop by, be sure to check out abeautiful memento. From 10 AM to 5 PM (with tours from 10 AM to 3 PM), the facility is open Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday. A reminder: Closed to the public on Saturdays (No Tours) but our gift shop and Ice Cream Parlor will be open 9am-2pm. Please be advised that the center is closed on Wednesdays and Sundays.

4.  Apple Valley Orchard

Location: 351 Weese Road SE, Cleveland, TN 37323

At Apple Valley Orchard in Cleveland, TN you will find not just an orchard but a historical landmark that has provided generations of local with the iconic chunk of Tennessee farm life. This hobby farm has grown to 40 acres of land, and over the years we have found space for more than 15,000 apple trees. The result: It quickly transformed into a must-visit for those locals and visitors craving fresh apple pie or other baked treats, not to mention the quiet kind of charm you can only find in rural American locations.

Apple Valley Orchard makes for a great location to bring the family, particularly if you have little ones! Its a year round orchard that is very popular during harvest season where you can pick your own apples which starts in the middle of july and goes on to Fall. This period is when the orchard extends its hours to cater for large numbers of visitors coming out to pick delicious apples and devouring seasonal delights from their bakery.

Its bakery is especially noteworthy, serving apple cider and fried apple pies (among other tasty treats). These are the items receiving rave reviews with Southern Living Magazine naming their fried apple pies one of the best in America. The orchard also sells fresh apple cider, slushies and many flavors of jams & jellies from their crops as well.

Apple Valley Orchard is perfect for young families. Kids can be Kids here while learning about apple farming, the process of making cider and riding through the bulked-lined rows on wagons pulled by a tractor. You can ride them on weekends throughout the peak fall season (already under way, but available through Oct. 28) for a little extra seasonal fun.

Best time to go: Visit the orchard during apple harvest in September and October, on weekends for a farm experience. We recommend coming early, especially on weekends when the orchard can get rather busy with families and apple aficionados. That can be especially true in the packed tractor rides.

5.  Lucky Ladd Farms

Location: 4374 Rocky Glade Road, Eagleville, TN 37060

Lucky Ladd Farms is one of the most memorable family destinations in Middle Tennessee featuring a unique blend of farming and fun with dozens of hands-on activities - excitement for all ages! This barnyard includes 60 acres of land and is considered by many to be the largest petting farm in TN – it boasts itself as one of Nashville's top destinations for family fun.

Those who visit Lucky Ladd Farms will find a plethora of activities beyond the typical farm experience. The petting farm is a favourite, where kids and adults can meet more than 100 animals from familiar farm types to some exotic beasts. Besides the animals, it also has mansion slides, a wagon ride down to another farm with pony rides and a splash pad making it an experience for all!

Those interested in a more educational visit will find exhibits and nature trails detailing farm life as well the natural world. The farm also offers seasonal attractions: pumpkin patch in the fall, flower-picking events in spring.

Lucky Ladd FarmsYulefest excels in being an event that is family-friendly, especially for those with younger children. The farm is laid out for fun AND safety so lots and LOTS of room to roam. With loads of playgrounds and adventure areas to burn off excitement, the educational exhibits make for a good chance to learn practically.

Relying on seasonal business, Lucky Ladd Farms closes through the winter months but can draw upwards of 30K visitors from when they reopen in April for their Spring Season up until Halloween is over. Located at 4374 Rocky Glade Road in Eagleville, Tennessee, the farm is located close to Nashville so it makes for a great day trip for families travelling through.

Families that visit Lucky Ladd Farms rave about all the fun things to do and what a wholesome place it is. Animal encounters are particularly popular with children, and the seasonal events mentioned regularly as best bits. Still, some people have complained of accessibility and a lackluster customer service experience for those with mobility limitations.
Two cows stand peacefully in a wide-open pasture

6.  Bird Fork Farm

Location: Near Dunlap, TN (Cumberland Plateau)

Nestled in Chattanooga, TN, Bird Fork Farm also deserves to be highlighted as a visionary endeavor that exemplifies holistic approaches towards sustainable and regenerative agriculture. Nestled on 55 acres of hillside in the rolling hills of Tennessee's Cumberland Plateau, this woman-run farm has become renowned for its incredible produce—a wonderful selection grown with zero pesticides and clearly a genuine heart-centered connection to ecology.

Bird Fork Farm puts their heart and soul into raising clean food, not trying to participate in agritourism like many typical farms. A Certified Naturally Grown farm, which is recognized by the U. S. Department of Agriculture, but also has standards stricter than those of organic certification Permaculture practices inform the growth of an expansive orchard containing literally tons of fruits and vegetables including: apples, pears, garlic scapes; herbs such as sage and cilantro — all on a variety plot that keeps yields high while keeping soils healthy for generations to come.

Bird Fork Farm sells its products at a variety of farmers markets in the area, including Main Street Farmers Market in Chattanooga. Hipcamp also has camping options for those who want to visit the farm in person, which will provide a much more “in-the-weeds” experience. Guests are welcome to camp at several scenic sites on the farm, including open pastures and wooded areas, while participating in everything from hiking trails to checking out some of the nearby state parks.

While Bird Fork Farm doesn't have playgrounds or petting zoos, its appeal to families looking for nature is less overt. Its educational component is what attracts many to the farm, particularly families looking for ways of including children in food origins and sustainable farming. Kids can go wild in the open spaces, smile at plants or get behind upcoming workshops that focus on everything natural.

One of the few times to interact with Bird Fork Farm is at a farmers' market where they sell their produce. Chattanooga — Main Street Farmers Market (year-round market, Wednesday from 4 to 6 PM) The lush landscape makes for a great setting to have Ontario agri-tourism experience within an easy, scenic drive: + During the warmer months visitors may CAMP right on the farm (just mellows that small part with electricity and some roughing it needed).

The response burden by their trusted customers is a testament to the farm's dedication to sustainability and product quality. Overall, the place has received rave reviews from campers who have stayed on the farm through Hipcamp for its peaceful setting and nearness to things people would do outdoors—all perfect criteria when getting away from urban life.

7.  Copper Creek Farm

Location: 1514 Reeves Station Rd SW, Calhoun, GA 30701

Copper Creek Farm in Calhoun, GA is a family-friendly destination for guests of all ages to enjoy. At the base of the Appalachians, this farm in North Georgia is dedicated to combining traditional farming with new-age entertainment; and for that alone it stands out.

Copper Creek Farm is well known for their seasonal events, bringing people from all over the Southeast. The farm's Park Calendar is filled with activities for all ages and interests so it remains an attraction throughout the year. The Sunflower Festival is another popular outdoor event that happens across Brooklyn in summer, allowing visitors to see the rows and rolls of bright golden petals through photography or just recreational activities. But as the leaves change, it becomes a fall wonderland with its massive corn maze, pumpkin patch and family activities such as pig races and gem mining.

Copper Creek Farm — open seasonally, based on events The Sunflower Festival in the summer and fall harvests when the farm is hopping with activities are good times of year to visit. But get there early, because it can be very crowded on the weekends. Parking is free of charge but gets so bad later in the day that it's best to go very early.

Copper Creek Farm is noted for being especially family-friendly with Park-wide appeal. Activities at the farm are made for children and adults, allowing families to spend a day together. These attractions are perfect for even the youngest visitors, providing hillbilly splash pad pony rides and more. The farm now has a General Store, which makes for an adorable shopping experience —albeit very short— where guests can purchase wonderful local products such as glazed pecans, goat soap and honey available depending on seasonal availablity and time of year.

Copper Creek Farm is open seasonally, aligning its operating hours with its major events. The best times to visit are during the Sunflower Festival in the summer and the fall harvest season when the farm is in full swing with activities. However, visitors should plan ahead, as the farm can get quite busy, especially on weekends. It’s advisable to arrive early to avoid traffic and secure good parking.

Reviews from past visitors often highlight the variety of activities and the overall enjoyment of the experience. However, some have noted that traffic and parking can be an issue during peak times, so planning your visit carefully is recommended.

Copper Creek Farm is an experience, not just a farm. Thanks to its seasonal events, broad range of activities and family-friendly feel the farm attracts families in their droves for a day out on the rural fringes. Whether you are tromping through sunflower fields, trekking a corn maze or just wanting the perfect picnic day with your family, Copper Creek Farm gives everyone what they need to make their visit well-rounded and fun.

With some of the farms so close to Chattanooga; it's not only a nice change up from your regular routine, but an opportunity to get in touch with the land and our communities, build relationships with those who grow or cook what we eat on a daily basis. Stroll through Crabtree Farms and witness the influence of urban agriculture combine with sustainable farming as you join in community-driven gatherings that unite people. On the other hand, Hidden Hills Farm & Saddle Club offers visitors a first-hand glimpse into country life: horseback riding (or pony rides), kids' farm play days or just taking in beautiful views of rolling countryside. But, more than destinations to experience here and now; these are the farms on which you can create lasting memories with friends and family, gain a hands-on agricultural education or simply lift up your community. Whether you are local to the area or just passing through, definitely check out these farms and see why they add such value to Chattanooga as a whole.
